segment.source: Update and manage Windows Defender in Windows 10 (Windows 10)
segment.target: Update and manage Windows Defender in Windows 10 (Windows 10)

segment.source: IT professionals can manage Windows Defender on Windows 10 endpoints in their organization using Microsoft Active Directory or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), apply updates to endpoints, and manage scans using Group Policy SettingsWindows Management Instrumentation (WMI)PowerShell.
segment.target: IT professionals can manage Windows Defender on Windows 10 endpoints in their organization using Microsoft Active Directory or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), apply updates to endpoints, and manage scans using Group Policy SettingsWindows Management Instrumentation (WMI)PowerShell.

segment.source: Update and manage Windows Defender in Windows 10
segment.target: Update and manage Windows Defender in Windows 10

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: IT professionals can manage Windows Defender on Windows 10 endpoints in their organization using Microsoft Active Directory or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), apply updates to endpoints, and manage scans using:
segment.target: IT professionals can manage Windows Defender on Windows 10 endpoints in their organization using Microsoft Active Directory or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), apply updates to endpoints, and manage scans using:

segment.source: Group Policy Settings
segment.target: Group Policy Settings

segment.source: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)
segment.target: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)

segment.source: PowerShell
segment.target: PowerShell

segment.source: Manage Windows Defender endpoints through Active Directory and WSUS
segment.target: Manage Windows Defender endpoints through Active Directory and WSUS

segment.source: All Windows 10 endpoints are installed with Windows Defender and include support for management through:
segment.target: All Windows 10 endpoints are installed with Windows Defender and include support for management through:

segment.source: Active Directory
segment.target: Active Directory

segment.source: WSUS
segment.target: WSUS

segment.source: You can use the Active Directory to configure the settings; Group policies can be used for centralized configuration and enforcement of many Windows Defender settings including client user interface, scan settings, and exclusions.
segment.target: You can use the Active Directory to configure the settings; Group policies can be used for centralized configuration and enforcement of many Windows Defender settings including client user interface, scan settings, and exclusions.

segment.source: WSUS can be used to view basic update compliance and deploy updates manually or through automatic rules.
segment.target: WSUS can be used to view basic update compliance and deploy updates manually or through automatic rules.

segment.source: Note that System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager SP1, System Center 2012 Configuration Manager SP2, and Microsoft Intune can provide centralized management of Windows Defender, including:
segment.target: Note that System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager SP1, System Center 2012 Configuration Manager SP2, and Microsoft Intune can provide centralized management of Windows Defender, including:

segment.source: Settings management
segment.target: Settings management

segment.source: Definition update management
segment.target: Definition update management

segment.source: Alerts and alert management
segment.target: Alerts and alert management

segment.source: Reports and reporting
segment.target: Reports and reporting

segment.source: When you enable Endpoint Protection on your clients, it will install an additional management layer on Windows Defender to manage the in-box Windows Defender agent.
segment.target: When you enable Endpoint Protection on your clients, it will install an additional management layer on Windows Defender to manage the in-box Windows Defender agent.

segment.source: While the client user interface will still appear as Windows Defender, the management layer for System Center Endpoint Protection or Intune will be listed in the Add/Remove Programs control panel, though it will appear as if the full product is installed.
segment.target: While the client user interface will still appear as Windows Defender, the management layer for System Center Endpoint Protection or Intune will be listed in the Add/Remove Programs control panel, though it will appear as if the full product is installed.

segment.source: Learn more about managing Endpoint Protection:
segment.target: Learn more about managing Endpoint Protection:

segment.source: Help secure Windows PCs with Endpoint Protection for Microsoft Intune
segment.target: Help secure Windows PCs with Endpoint Protection for Microsoft Intune

segment.source: Endpoint Protection in Configuration Manager
segment.target: Endpoint Protection in Configuration Manager

segment.source: Read more about System Center Configuration Manager in Introduction to Endpoint Protection in Configuration Manager.
segment.target: Read more about System Center Configuration Manager in Introduction to Endpoint Protection in Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Important: You must be licensed to use Endpoint Protection to manage clients in your Configuration Manager hierarchy.
segment.target: Important: You must be licensed to use Endpoint Protection to manage clients in your Configuration Manager hierarchy.

segment.source: Apply updates to Windows Defender endpoints
segment.target: Apply updates to Windows Defender endpoints

segment.source: It is important to keep Windows Defender endpoints updated to ensure they are protected.
segment.target: It is important to keep Windows Defender endpoints updated to ensure they are protected.

segment.source: All Windows Defender updates, including General Distribution Release (GDR) updates, are now applied as operating system updates.
segment.target: All Windows Defender updates, including General Distribution Release (GDR) updates, are now applied as operating system updates.

segment.source: You can manage the distribution of updates through the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS).
segment.target: You can manage the distribution of updates through the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS).

segment.source: Manage email scans in Windows Defender
segment.target: Manage email scans in Windows Defender

segment.source: You can use Windows Defender to scan email files.
segment.target: You can use Windows Defender to scan email files.

segment.source: Malware can install itself and hide in email files, and although real-time protection offers you the best protection from email malware, you can also scan emails stored on your PC or server with Windows Defender.
segment.target: Malware can install itself and hide in email files, and although real-time protection offers you the best protection from email malware, you can also scan emails stored on your PC or server with Windows Defender.

segment.source: Important: Mail scanning only applies to on-demand and scheduled scans, not on-access scans.
segment.target: Important: Mail scanning only applies to on-demand and scheduled scans, not on-access scans.

segment.source: Windows Defender scans Microsoft Office Outlook 2003 and older email files.
segment.target: Windows Defender scans Microsoft Office Outlook 2003 and older email files.

segment.source: We identify the file type at run-time based on the content of the file, not on location or extension.
segment.target: We identify the file type at run-time based on the content of the file, not on location or extension.

segment.source: Note: Scanning email files might increase the time required to complete a scan.
segment.target: Note: Scanning email files might increase the time required to complete a scan.

segment.source: Windows Defender can extract embedded objects within a file (attachments and archived files, for example) and scan internally.
segment.target: Windows Defender can extract embedded objects within a file (attachments and archived files, for example) and scan internally.

segment.source: Note: While Windows Defender can be configured to scan email files, it can only remediate threats detected inside certain files, for example:
segment.target: Note: While Windows Defender can be configured to scan email files, it can only remediate threats detected inside certain files, for example:

segment.source: DBX
segment.target: DBX

segment.source: MBX
segment.target: MBX

segment.source: MIME
segment.target: MIME

segment.source: You can configure Windows Defender to scan PST files used by Outlook 2003 or older versions (where the archive type is set to non-uni-code), but Windows Defender cannot remediate threats detected inside PST files.
segment.target: You can configure Windows Defender to scan PST files used by Outlook 2003 or older versions (where the archive type is set to non-uni-code), but Windows Defender cannot remediate threats detected inside PST files.

segment.source: We recommend using real-time protection to protect against email malware.
segment.target: We recommend using real-time protection to protect against email malware.

segment.source: If Windows Defender detects a threat inside an email, it will show you the following information to assist you in identifying the compromised email, so you can remediate the threat:
segment.target: If Windows Defender detects a threat inside an email, it will show you the following information to assist you in identifying the compromised email, so you can remediate the threat:

segment.source: Email subject
segment.target: Email subject

segment.source: Attachment name Email scanning in Windows Defender is turned off by default.
segment.target: Attachment name Email scanning in Windows Defender is turned off by default.

segment.source: There are three ways you can manage scans through Windows Defender:
segment.target: There are three ways you can manage scans through Windows Defender:

segment.source: Group Policy settings
segment.target: Group Policy settings

segment.source: WMI
segment.target: WMI

segment.source: PowerShell
segment.target: PowerShell

segment.source: Important: There are some risks associated with scanning some Microsoft Outlook files and email messages.
segment.target: Important: There are some risks associated with scanning some Microsoft Outlook files and email messages.

segment.source: You can read about tips and risks associated with scanning Outlook files and email messages in the following articles:
segment.target: You can read about tips and risks associated with scanning Outlook files and email messages in the following articles:

segment.source: Scanning Outlook files in Outlook 2013
segment.target: Scanning Outlook files in Outlook 2013

segment.source: Scanning email messages in Outlook 2013
segment.target: Scanning email messages in Outlook 2013

segment.source: Use Group Policy settings to enable email scans
segment.target: Use Group Policy settings to enable email scans

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to turn on email scanning.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to turn on email scanning.

segment.source: When email scanning is enabled, the engine will parse the mailbox and mail files to analyze the mail bodies and attachments.
segment.target: When email scanning is enabled, the engine will parse the mailbox and mail files to analyze the mail bodies and attachments.

segment.source: Turn on email scanning with the following Group Policy settings:
segment.target: Turn on email scanning with the following Group Policy settings:

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.
segment.target: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.

segment.source: Click Scan.
segment.target: Click Scan.

segment.source: Double-click Turn on e-mail scanning.
segment.target: Double-click Turn on e-mail scanning.

segment.source: This will open the Turn on e-mail scanning window:
segment.target: This will open the Turn on e-mail scanning window:

segment.source: turn on e-mail scanning window
segment.target: turn on e-mail scanning window

segment.source: Select Enabled.
segment.target: Select Enabled.

segment.source: Click OK to apply changes.
segment.target: Click OK to apply changes.

segment.source: Use WMI to disable email scans
segment.target: Use WMI to disable email scans

segment.source: You can write a WMI script or application to disable email scanning.
segment.target: You can write a WMI script or application to disable email scanning.

segment.source: Read more about WMI in this article, and read about Windows Preference classes in this article.
segment.target: Read more about WMI in this article, and read about Windows Preference classes in this article.

segment.source: Use the DisableEmailScanning property of the MSFTMpPreference class (part of the Windows DefenderWMI provider) to enable or disable this setting: DisableEmailScanning Data type: boolean Access type: Read-only Disable email scanning.
segment.target: Use the DisableEmailScanning property of the MSFTMpPreference class (part of the Windows DefenderWMI provider) to enable or disable this setting: DisableEmailScanning Data type: boolean Access type: Read-only Disable email scanning.

segment.source: Use PowerShell to enable email scans
segment.target: Use PowerShell to enable email scans

segment.source: You can also enable email scanning using the following PowerShell parameter:
segment.target: You can also enable email scanning using the following PowerShell parameter:

segment.source: Open PowerShell or PowerShellIntegrated Scripting Environment (ISE).
segment.target: Open PowerShell or PowerShellIntegrated Scripting Environment (ISE).

segment.source: Type Set-MpPreference -DisableEmailScanning $false.
segment.target: Type Set-MpPreference -DisableEmailScanning $false.

segment.source: Read more about this in:
segment.target: Read more about this in:

segment.source: • Scripting with Windows PowerShell
segment.target: • Scripting with Windows PowerShell

segment.source: • Defender Cmdlets
segment.target: • Defender Cmdlets

segment.source: Manage archive scans in Windows Defender
segment.target: Manage archive scans in Windows Defender

segment.source: You can use Windows Defender to scan archive files.
segment.target: You can use Windows Defender to scan archive files.

segment.source: Malware can install itself and hide in archive files, and although real-time protection offers you the best protection from malware, you can also scan archives stored on your PC or server with Windows Defender.
segment.target: Malware can install itself and hide in archive files, and although real-time protection offers you the best protection from malware, you can also scan archives stored on your PC or server with Windows Defender.

segment.source: Important: Archive scanning only applies to on-demand and scheduled scans, not on-access scans.
segment.target: Important: Archive scanning only applies to on-demand and scheduled scans, not on-access scans.

segment.source: Archive scanning in Windows Defender is turned on by default.
segment.target: Archive scanning in Windows Defender is turned on by default.

segment.source: There are four ways you can manage scans through Windows Defender:
segment.target: There are four ways you can manage scans through Windows Defender:

segment.source: Group Policy settings
segment.target: Group Policy settings

segment.source: WMI
segment.target: WMI

segment.source: PowerShell
segment.target: PowerShell

segment.source: Endpoint Protection
segment.target: Endpoint Protection

segment.source: Note: Scanning archive files might increase the time required to complete a scan.
segment.target: Note: Scanning archive files might increase the time required to complete a scan.

segment.source: If you exclude an archive file type by using the Extensions box, Windows Defender will not scan files with that extension (no matter what the content is), even when you have selected the Scan archive files check box.
segment.target: If you exclude an archive file type by using the Extensions box, Windows Defender will not scan files with that extension (no matter what the content is), even when you have selected the Scan archive files check box.

segment.source: For example, if you exclude .rar files but there’s a .r00 file that’s actually .rar content, it will still be scanned if archive scanning is enabled.
segment.target: For example, if you exclude .rar files but there’s a .r00 file that’s actually .rar content, it will still be scanned if archive scanning is enabled.

segment.source: Use Group Policy settings to enable archive scans
segment.target: Use Group Policy settings to enable archive scans

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to turn on archive scanning.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to turn on archive scanning.

segment.source: Turn on email scanning with the following Group Policy settings:
segment.target: Turn on email scanning with the following Group Policy settings:

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.
segment.target: In the Local Computer Policy tree, expand Computer Configuration, then Administrative Templates, then Windows Components, then Windows Defender.

segment.source: Click Scan.
segment.target: Click Scan.

segment.source: Double-click Scan archive files.
segment.target: Double-click Scan archive files.

segment.source: This will open the Scan archive files window:
segment.target: This will open the Scan archive files window:

segment.source: scan archive files window
segment.target: scan archive files window

segment.source: Select Enabled.
segment.target: Select Enabled.

segment.source: Click OK to apply changes.
segment.target: Click OK to apply changes.

segment.source: There are a number of archive scan settings in the Scan repository you can configure through Group Policy, for example:
segment.target: There are a number of archive scan settings in the Scan repository you can configure through Group Policy, for example:

segment.source: Maximum directory depth level into which archive files are unpacked during scanning
segment.target: Maximum directory depth level into which archive files are unpacked during scanning

segment.source: specify the maximum depth to scan archive files window
segment.target: specify the maximum depth to scan archive files window

segment.source: Maximum size of archive files that will be scanned
segment.target: Maximum size of archive files that will be scanned

segment.source: specify the maximum size of archive files to be scanned window
segment.target: specify the maximum size of archive files to be scanned window

segment.source: Maximum percentage CPU utilization permitted during a scan
segment.target: Maximum percentage CPU utilization permitted during a scan

segment.source: specify the maximum percentage od cpu utilization during a scan window
segment.target: specify the maximum percentage od cpu utilization during a scan window

segment.source: Use WMI to disable archive scans
segment.target: Use WMI to disable archive scans

segment.source: You can write a WMI script or application to disable archive scanning.
segment.target: You can write a WMI script or application to disable archive scanning.

segment.source: Read more about WMI in this article, and read about Windows Preference classes in this article.
segment.target: Read more about WMI in this article, and read about Windows Preference classes in this article.

segment.source: Use the DisableArchiveScanning property of the MSFTMpPreference class (part of the Windows DefenderWMI provider) to enable or disable this setting: DisableArchiveScanning Data type: boolean Access type: Read-only Disable archive scanning.
segment.target: Use the DisableArchiveScanning property of the MSFTMpPreference class (part of the Windows DefenderWMI provider) to enable or disable this setting: DisableArchiveScanning Data type: boolean Access type: Read-only Disable archive scanning.

segment.source: Use PowerShell to enable archive scans
segment.target: Use PowerShell to enable archive scans

segment.source: You can also enable archive scanning using the following PowerShell parameter:
segment.target: You can also enable archive scanning using the following PowerShell parameter:

segment.source: Open PowerShell or PowerShellISE.
segment.target: Open PowerShell or PowerShellISE.

segment.source: Type Set-MpPreference -DisableArchiveScanning $false.
segment.target: Type Set-MpPreference -DisableArchiveScanning $false.

segment.source: Read more about this in:
segment.target: Read more about this in:

segment.source: Scripting with Windows PowerShell
segment.target: Scripting with Windows PowerShell

segment.source: Defender Cmdlets
segment.target: Defender Cmdlets

segment.source: Use Endpoint Protection to configure archive scans
segment.target: Use Endpoint Protection to configure archive scans

segment.source: In Endpoint Protection, you can use the advanced scanning options to configure archive scanning.
segment.target: In Endpoint Protection, you can use the advanced scanning options to configure archive scanning.

segment.source: For more information, see What are advanced scanning options?
segment.target: For more information, see What are advanced scanning options?
